bibl.title: Notes from Henry Rose Carter to M.J. Rosenau, [19--]

div1.p: Carter provides Rosenau with notes from his book on yellow fever. He discusses the origins of yellow fever, as well as other points about yellow fever and malaria.

div1.head: Notes from Henry Rose Carter to M.J. Rosenau, [19--]
div1.p:
Book
Rosenau

Notes, For Dr. Rosenau
(On Section 111. History of Yellow Fever.)

Page 1, MS: Your suggestion that the original place of origin of yellow
fever (“where the triple alliance between mosquito: parasite and man
established itself”) may have ceased to be an endemic focus before
the West Coast of Africa and the Americas became infected, is entirely
possible.

One can easily conceive of a region infected with yellow fever be-
ing freed from it by some change--sociological: biological or climat-
ic--but which prior to this had infected some other place where the
infection remained permanently. The present infection in Brazil
quite surely came from New Orleans or Havana (1849) both of which are
now free from it, the first spontaneously, while that in Brazil still
exists. The island of Grenada infected the Guianas and freed itself
long before they did.

I think when I said “origin” I was thinking less of where the in-
fection--the paracitism pathogenic to man of this organism--was evolv-
ed-than where it was first found in historic (or traditional) times.

It is a question to me, however, if the “mosquito, the micro-organ-
ism and man” were the original group which determined the parasitism
of this organism--I think we can assume it as originally free living.
I should think that the parasitism of any organism would be more apt
to be developed in a host to which it was not pathogenic, or at least
not seriously pathogenic. If so, the probabilities are (1) that if
the parasitism of this organism was developed with man as a host it
was not at that time pathogenic to man: or (2) its developement of
parasitism took place in some animal other than man to which it was
not pathogenic.

If the 1st.: pathogenicity to man was a subsequent evolution in
in
Notes. Page 2.
man: If the 2nd., although not pathogenic to its host in which para-
sitism was developed, it may have been so to man from the beginning.

For the first we have indeed the analogy of the change of virulence
of a number of infections, indeed of yellow fever itself, but I know
of nothing that would lead us to think that at one time the yellow
fever organism was not pathogenic to man and generally so. It is pos-
sible, but does not seem at all probable.

For the 2nd. there is the analogy we now find in a number of in-
fections: Rocky Mountain fever: sleeping sickness: Chagas' disease etc.
Such a host-of-evolution (resevoir host?) might (a) have ceased to
exist or (b) if still existent to be looked for especially in the re-
gions in which this evolution took place, or in regions in which bio-
logical conditions are similar to those then existing in that region.

It is fair to say that for man to have been a necessary link in
the survival of this organism--the conditions for this being the same
as to-day--implies so dense a population, or so much intercommunica-
tion among men that this could not have occurred among what we are
accustomed to call “primitive men.” A population of hunters or fish-
ers could not have maintained as a second host the life of this organ-
ism if the requisites for this were the same as at present.

The evidence seems then to be ( ) that yellow fever did not ex-
ist among primitive men and hence is not a very old human infection or
( ) if it did, that it was kept alive by some other animal besides
man acting as second (and resevoir?) host.

Note in this connection that its mosquito vector is considered by
entomologists one of the more recent mosquitoes--not old like Anopheles
and some others.

See how far afield this has carried me. Nevertheless I am inclined
to think (note the “inclined,” I am not really thinking it) that the
evolution to parasitism of the causative organism of yellow fever took
took
Notes. Page 3.
place in some animal other than man as the third member of your tri-
ple alliance and probably its pathogenicity to man as well.
Page 4, MS: Stegomyia in Asia:

(1) See quotation from Edward's letter, “very rare” in Asia “except
in seaports” etc.

(2) Had the south-eastern part of Asia, where Stegomyia now abound,
ever been infected, with the dense population it has had for centu-
ries and the vector as numerous as, if indigenous, they would be from
the universal habit of storing water for domestic use, the chance of
its spontaneous elimination therefrom had been practically nil. Yet
we have not found it in Asia--and we have a very long history of south-
eastern Asia.

Also I am going to send you a carbon of a paper I wrote some time
ago, at the request of the Australians, on this subject.

Page 7, MS: 600,000 Indians in Jamaica. It may be; the most one can
say is that these are guess estimates.

Page 13, MS: “yellow fever possibly endemic in tierra caliente without
provoking epidemics to come to special notice in codices or anales.”

Not permanently endemic there, I think, without epidemics appearing
from time to time among the expeditions sent down from the plateau,
which, I judge, would have been noticed. These were frequent after
1458, “when Moctecuma subjugated the province of Chicoaque near Panuco.”
Page 39, MS: “community depopulated by malaria?”

This is practically true for white people in the rural section of
much of tide-water Virginia: of the coast of South Carolina and Ga.; of
the Yazoo delta etc. Negroes live there--too few whites to count. I
judge that we can put much of Greece: the Roman Campagna and some other
parts of Italy in the same category. “Things of continuance or of fre-
quent recurrence be in two categories: to the one we become accustomed;
the other we become tired of:” And malaria falls distinctly in the lat-
lat-
Notes. Page 4.
ter class.

Page 40, MS: “neither yellow fever nor malaria about Vera Cruz” when
Cortez came. I agree. I think that there was no malaria in the Ameri-
cas before the Spaniards (and negroes) came. Wrote a memo, for L. L. Williams
on this subject.
Obiter Dicta.

Again your “triple alliance.” Does not the West Coast of Africa
seem to be the very home of spirochetes (or is spironemata the up-
to-date word?) pathogenic to man? There have been reported from this
region a variety of infections of men with (reportedly) different spi-
rochetes and there seem to be here more different species of this or-
ganism pathogenic to man, and in greater abundance, than in any other
part of the world. Many of these infections in man are somewhat like,
and some (as reported) are very like, yellow fever; and, if we accept
the organism of Noguchi as the one causative of yellow fever, the num-
ber of species of spirochetes pathogenic to man in this region might
be the basis of an argument for this being the region in which a spi-
rochete causing yellow fever in man was evolved!

Whether the similarity of the human reactions to these West African
infections and in yellow fever could be held to imply a general similar-
ity in their toxins is doubtful. If so, it would, more or less, cor-
respond to the similarity of the biology of Stegomyia aegypti and the
some other African coast Stegomyia.

Fanciful? yes; and I don't know enough about the West African
spirochetes nor the possibilities of the evolution of any spirochete
to have an opinion on this matter. Only it seems to dove-tail in
with all the rest.
